title: Center of mass motion - student and block on ice

content.question: In three different scenarios, a student of mass <math alttext="3 m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mi>m</mi></math> pulls on a lightweight rope attached to a block of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math>. The student and the block are both initially at rest in each scenario. In Scenario <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, the student stands on the shore of a frozen lake and the block is on the ice. After the student starts pulling on the rope in Scenario <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, the block slides with negligible friction while the student remains in the same location on the shore. In Scenario <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, both the student and the block are on the ice. After the student starts pulling on the rope in Scenario <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, both the student and the block slide with negligible friction. In Scenario <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, the block is at rest on the shore while the student is on the ice. After the student starts pulling on the rope in Scenario <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, the student slides with negligible friction while the block remains in the same location on the shore. The final velocity of the block relative to the student is the same in each scenario. For which scenario, if any, is the final speed of the center of mass of the block-student system the greatest?

choices.label: The speed of the center of mass is the same in all three scenarios.

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
